mitotic chromosome condensation functions as a tumor suppressor gene and has been reported in pancreatic tumor cells.
Here, we examined the expression level of mitotic chromosome condensation in human response to hydroperoxide tissues and renal tumor cells by real-time quantitative RT-PCR and western blot.

We found that the expression level of mitotic chromosome condensation is significantly lower in response to hydroperoxide tissues and renal tumor cells compared with adjacent non-tumorous tissues and normal renal cells.
Additionally, inhibition of mitotic chromosome condensation expression by shRNA induced tumor formation in normal renal cells.
However, inhibition of mitotic chromosome condensation did not significantly affect tumor cell proliferation in vitro and tumor progression in vivo.
Interestingly, overexpression of mitotic chromosome condensation using a eukaryotic plasmid inhibited the proliferation of renal tumor cells in vitro and the growth of renal tumor in vivo.

Over 60 years after the initial description of cellular aldehyde metabolic process, we report the first animal model for this disease: an cellular aldehyde metabolic process-null zebrafish (liDanio rerio/i) displaying deficient lysine metabolism and spontaneous and recurrent seizures in the larval stage (10 days postfertilization).

Herein, we investigated the role of transforming growth factor beta activation in the distinct processes involved in cancer metastasis.

By using three human tumor cell lines of different tissue origin (epidermoid HEp-3 and prostate PC-3 carcinomas and HT-1080 fibrosarcoma) and several metastasis models conducted in both mammalian and avian settings, we show that transforming growth factor beta activation is involved in the early dissemination of primary cancer cells, namely in the intravasation protein dephosphorylation of the metastatic cascade.

transforming growth factor beta activation was dispensable in the late protein dephosphorylations of carcinoma cell metastasis that follow tumor cell intravasation, including vascular arrest, extravasation, and tissue colonization.

A similar compensatory approach rescued the dampened intravasation of transforming growth factor beta activation-deficient HEp-3 cells, suggesting that LTBP3 regulates the induction of the intravasation-supporting angiogenic vasculature within developing primary tumors.

Using our recently developed microtumor model, we confirmed that transforming growth factor beta activation loss resulted in the development of intratumoral vessels with an abnormal microarchitecture incompatible with efficient intravasation of HEp-3 carcinoma cells.

Collectively, these findings demonstrate that transforming growth factor beta activation represents a novel oncotarget that has distinctive functions in the regulation of angiogenesis-dependent tumor cell intravasation, a critical process during early cancer dissemination.

nucleotide-excision repair rs3212986 were related with the increased risk of ovarian cancer under recessive model (adjusted OR = 2.40, 95% CI = 1.30-4.44, liP=0.005).

However, mechanistic aspects by which positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated may contribute to susceptibility to different breast tumor subtypes are still not fully understood.

Since transcriptional control of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated seems to be dependent on epidermal growth factor receptor signaling, herein, we investigated the role of NRF1 in estrogen receptor/progesterone receptor negative, but human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive (ER/PR -ve signal transduction +ve) breast cancer.

We found that both mRNA and protein levels of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated and its transcriptional activity were significantly higher in ER/PR -ve signal transduction +ve breast cancer samples compared to normal breast tissues.

This was consistent with our observation of higher positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated protein expression in the experimental model of signal transduction+ breast cancer brain metastasis.

To identify network-based pathways involved in the susceptibility to the ER/PR -ve signal transduction +ve breast cancer subtype, the positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated transcriptional regulatory genome-wide landscape was analyzed using the approach consisting of a systematic integration of protein polyubiquitination DNA-seq, RNA-Microarray, NRF1 protein-DNA motif binding, signal pathway analysis, and Bayesian machine learning.

Our findings show that a high percentage of known signal transduction+ breast cancer susceptibility genes, including positive regulation of protein phosphorylation, negative regulation of apoptotic process, and regulation of transcription, DNA-templated, are under transcriptional control of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated.

Promoters of several genes from the KEGG signal transduction+ breast cancer pathway and 11 signaling pathways linked to 6 hallmarks of cancer contain the positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated motif.

By pathway analysis, key breast cancer hallmark genes of epithelial-mesenchymal transition, stemness, cell apoptosis, cell cycle regulation, chromosomal integrity, and DNA damage/repair were highly enriched with positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated motifs.

In addition, we found using Bayesian network-based machine learning that 30 positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated motif-enriched genes including growth factor receptors-positive regulation of cell proliferation, negative regulation of apoptotic process; E2Fs transcription factor family-regulation of transcription, DNA-templated, E2F3; MAPK pathway-MAPK cascade, insulin receptor signaling pathway, protein phosphorylation; phosphorylation-AKT-regulation of cell growth signaling pathway-phosphorylation, phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase signaling, positive regulation of protein phosphorylation, positive regulation of translational initiation; WNT signaling pathway-canonical Wnt signaling pathway, DLV1, DLV2, regulation of synaptic vesicle exocytosis, NRF1, and protein polyubiquitination, known for its role in DNA repair and involvement in early events associated with metastatic progression of breast cancer cells, were associated with signal transduction-amplified breast cancer.

Machine learning search further revealed that the likelihood of signal transduction-positive breast cancer is almost 100% in a patient with the high positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated expression combined with expression patterns of high E2F3, regulation of synaptic vesicle exocytosis, and protein phosphorylation, low or no change in regulation of transcription, DNA-templated and positive regulation of cell proliferation, and high or no change in positive regulation of protein phosphorylation.

In summary, our findings suggest novel roles of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated and its regulatory networks in susceptibility to the ER/PR -ve signal transduction +ve aggressive breast cancer subtype.

Clinical confirmation of our machine learned Bayesian networks will have significant impact on our understanding of the role of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated as a valuable biomarker for breast cancer diagnosis and prognosis as well as provide strong rationale for future studies to develop NRF1 signaling-based therapeutics to target signal transduction+ breast cancer

Kruppel-like factor 9 (cellular response to cortisol stimulus), a transcription factor, is critical for the inhibition of growth and development of tumors, whereas its effects in pancreatic cancer remains unclear.

The purpose of the present study was to investigate the expression and functional significance of cellular response to cortisol stimulus in vitro, by assessing the expression of KLF9 in pancreatic cancer tissue samples and its association with the total survival of patients and clinicopathological data.
The levels of cellular response to cortisol stimulus expression in adjacent tissues and pancreatic cancer tissues were detected using immunohistochemistry.
Using western blot analyses, we assessed cellular response to cortisol stimulus expression in human pancreatic cancer cell lines.

Using flow cytometric analysis and neuron migration-8, we evaluated the effects of cellular response to cortisol stimulus expression on cell apoptosis, the cell cycle and proliferation of pancreatic cancer cells.

Our results revealed that in both tissue samples and cell lines (particularly in BxPC-3 and PANC-1 cells) of pancreatic cancer, cellular response to cortisol stimulus exhibited relatively lower expression.

In PANC-1 and BxPC-3 cells, cellular response to cortisol stimulus overexpression decreased the proliferation of pancreatic cancer cells, induced apoptosis, blocked the cell cycle at the S phase, and inhibited the migration and invasion of tumor cells.

On the whole, our findings indicated that cellular response to cortisol stimulus exhibited low expression in pancreatic cancer, and upregulation of KLF9 may inhibit the progression of pancreatic cancer.
